header_summary:
Antoine Poinsot and colleagues have worked to address vulnerabilities in the Bitcoin protocol, inspired by Matt Corallo's 2019 Great Consensus Cleanup proposal, focusing on enhancing security and efficiency. This includes measures against the timewarp and Murch-Zawy attacks, caps on legacy transaction signatures, and improvements to merkle tree integrity, culminating in a draft Bitcoin Improvement Proposal ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/jiyMlvTX8BnG71f75SqChQZxyhZDQ65kldcugeIDJVJsvK4hadCO3GT46xFc7_cUlWdmOCG0B_WIz0HAO5ZugqYTuX5qxnNLRBn3MopuATI=@protonmail.com/T/#u#m77411f8b5e3d276ac95e30368f2a78c66d06ef3d)).

Significant progress has been reported by Murch in refining the Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) procedure, marking its transition from a private endeavor to a more public review phase, and calling for community feedback to further enhance the proposal ([view the proposal](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/pull/1712)).

Advancements in TRUC channels have been highlighted, notably the elimination of the need for nodes to monitor mempools, leading to simpler code and benefits for mobile applications. Discussions have focused on mitigating fee griefing and dust theft, with proposals to adopt specific options for handling dust HTLCs and anchor scripts, aiming to balance security and efficiency without adding undue complexity ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/which-ephemeral-anchor-script-should-lightning-use/1412/8)).

Sr-gi's exploration into optimizing Bitcoin network bandwidth through the Erlay protocol suggests adjusting fanout rates during transaction propagation can significantly reduce redundancy and improve efficiency. Simulations indicate that a balanced approach to fanout rates can achieve faster transaction propagation with minimal bandwidth increase, presenting a promising strategy for enhancing network performance ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/erlay-define-fanout-rate-based-on-the-transaction-reception-method/1422)).

Lastly, an analysis by 0xB10C on network activity unveiled a concerning volume of orphan transaction removals, hinting at potential network flooding attempts. The study calls for improved transaction management systems to handle such anomalies more effectively, ensuring the network's robustness against deliberate flooding tactics ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/stats-on-orphanage-overflows/1421/2)).

recent_posts.title: Update on the Great Consensus Cleanup Revival
recent_posts.summary:
- The community aims to enhance Bitcoin's security through Matt Corallo's proposal.
- Critical updates include mechanisms against the timewarp and Murch-Zawy attacks, and improvements in merkle tree security.
- A draft Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) is in progress to address these threats.

recent_posts.title: Finished planned work on BIP 3: Updated BIP Process
recent_posts.summary:
- The BIP updating process advanced, culminating in BIP 3's early January designation.
- The developer invites community feedback and suggestions on the GitHub pull request.
- This effort seeks to refine the BIP process, encouraging broad and inclusive participation.

recent_posts.title: Which ephemeral anchor script should lightning use?
recent_posts.summary:
- Significant progress in TRUC channels with nodes not needing to monitor mempools.
- Recommends adopting Option 2 with changes for handling dust HTLCs to address fee griefing and dust theft.
- Proposes keyed anchors to reduce griefing, with innovations to prevent dust HTLC theft effectively.

recent_posts.title: Erlay: Define fanout rate based on the transaction reception method
recent_posts.summary:
- The blog post examines Erlay protocol's use in improving network bandwidth for Bitcoin transactions.
- It suggests adjusting fanout rates based on transaction stages enhances efficiency and reduces latency.
- Simulations show a specific configuration achieves an 18% speed improvement with minimal bandwidth increase.

recent_posts.title: Stats on orphanage overflows
recent_posts.summary:
- Network analysis on September 14, 2024, showed unexpected high transaction removals, especially from node alice.
- Over 99% of removed transactions were 501 or 502 WU, hinting at a link to runestone mints.
- Investigations revealed massive transaction solicitations, pointing to systemic inefficiencies needing addressal.

active_posts.title: Reiterating centralized coinjoin (Wasabi & Samourai) deanonymization attacks
active_posts.summary:
- Vulnerabilities in Wasabi & GingerWallet reveal significant deanonymization risks due to protocol flaws.
- Whirlpool's flaw allows malicious coordinators to deanonymize transactions through unique RSA key manipulation.
- The economic incentives in the system fail to prevent user fund thefts, undermining financial security.

active_posts.title: Call for reconfiguration of nodes to relay transactions with fee-rates below 1 sat/vbyte
active_posts.summary:
- The Bitcoin node's minimum relay fee has been static at 1 sat/vbyte since 2013.
- A proposal suggests lowering the `minrelaytxfee` to 0.001 sat/vbyte to ease transaction fees.
- This change aims to improve efficiency for consolidation and multisig transactions in the Bitcoin network.

active_posts.title: Transaction expiration should be based on the most recent transaction in a group, not the first
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core development deals with transaction expiration based on entry time in the mempool.
- Critics argue this system is inefficient, prone to DoS attacks, and affects transaction longevity.
- The debate involves the necessity and impact of transaction expiration on Bitcoin's network management.

active_posts.title: Great Consensus Cleanup Revival
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal reviews Bitcoin's protocol flaws, suggesting improvements for security and efficiency.
- It highlights the timewarp exploit and proposes adjusting mining retarget periods for safety.
- Calls for community input on refining Bitcoin, while debating block size reduction's impact on scalability.

active_posts.title: Timewarp attack 600 second grace period
active_posts.summary:
- Matt Corallo's proposal focuses on `nTime` rolling limits in Bitcoin mining.
- Current testnet adjustments allow 600 seconds for backward `nTime` shifts.
- Discussions suggest increasing this to two hours, reducing potential timestamp exploits.

active_posts.title: ZK-gossip for lightning channel announcements
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal enhances privacy in taproot gossip protocols using Utreexo and ZK-proofs.
- It introduces `channel_announcement_2` and `channel_announcement_zk` for anonymous channel verification.
- Feedback is sought for this privacy-focused extension to improve Lightning Network operations.

today_in_history_posts.title: Purge attacks (spin on sabotage attacks)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Mike Kelly suggested ending transaction replacement for consensus compatibility in January.
- Hasu identified a sabotage attack, "The Purge," undermining Bitcoin by enabling double-spending.
- Mitigation strategies against such attacks are explored in a detailed report linked.

today_in_history_posts.title: DRAFT: interactive tx construction protocol
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Rusty proposes adding a unique serial_id to transaction inputs and outputs for improvements.
- Serial ids replace BIP69, sorting inputs and outputs, with odd for initiators, even for non-initiators.
- Serial ids also identify input/output removals and guide witness ordering, with specific conditions for usage.

today_in_history_posts.title: V3 and some possible futures
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The V3 policy focuses on one parent-child transaction limit, reducing pinning but has limitations.
- Future proposals like V3.0.5 and V4 series aim to enhance flexibility and address current policy constraints.
- The goal is a robust, adaptable transaction policy framework suitable for a dynamic mempool landscape.
